unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Attendance Records
question_text:
A secretary at a local high school keeps track of the attendance records of all students at the high school.
The secretary randomly selects $40\text{ students}$ from the records and constructs a $95\%$ confidence interval to estimate the average number of days students miss per year.
Why would it be incorrect for the secretary to construct a confidence interval for this data?

choices.text: This problem does not differentiate between the categorical reasons for being absent.
It does not make sense to construct a confidence interval when the population data is known.
A distribution such as this one is likely to have data that is strongly skewed to the right.
The sample size is too small for the assumptions to be met.
It is impossible to find the critical $T^*$ value for a problem such as this.
